column4: What's the ls command for listing something containing specific text? Such as ".wav"?
are you trying to find text inside of files?
no, simply files containing certain texts within a directory
via the command line:P
will that give me a list of all files with ".wav" in them?
I'm looking for files with those labels on them, not directories:D
if you are looking for files that end with .wav, that is how you do it.
I told you... ls /path/*.wav
ls: cannot access /path/*.wav: No such file or directory
you replace /path/ with the path of the directory you want to list
oh, haha... how embarrassing:/
I keep getting "no such file or directory":-S
put here what you are typing in a terminal
sirriffsalot@aspire:~$ ls /home/sirriffsalot/Music/*.wav for example
find ~/Music/ -type f -name '*.wav'
whoooa
surprisingly few .wav files there, cheers mate!=)
lspci -nn | grep VGA

03:00.0 VGA compatible controller [0300]: NVIDIA Corporation G98 [GeForce G 100] [10de:06e6] (rev a1)  and 02:00.0 VGA compatible controller [0300]: NVIDIA Corporation C77 [GeForce 8200] [10de:084b] (rev a2)
I get those two lines as output..
are you trying to use both your onboard and the card?
No idea... not intentionally at least:S
disable the onboard in bios
so the (rev 2) GeForce 8200?
I would expect that that is your onboard.  however in the bios it will likely identify as "onboard"
I'll have a look, thanks for suggesting! Brb
is this an asus m3n78 bpard by chance?
Hi... I went into the bios (I'm on a acer aspire machine) and I can't find any options to disable the graphics cards....... this is getting annoying lol
let me look at something
It's an acer aspire x3200...
can you please tell me the output of apt-cache policy nvidia-current | grep Installed
hmm Installed: (none)
if I were you, I would sudo apt-get install nvidia-current-updates
trying that then, finger crossed:)
nvidia-current-updates nvidia-settings-updates these two packages were going to be installed as a result... sound right?
praying for some luck...:D
alright, shall I just reboot now when it's finished installing?
haha:) cheers. rebooting then. *prays incessantly*
Now my system details says I have "GeForce G100/PCIe/SSE2 " as a driver:D
in what way?
logging in to the game:P
as a side benefit... you can likely use multiple monitors, and enable twinview in the nvidia config gui.
don't have enough space for that
Hang on
FPS went from 12-18 to -25-30!!
you're my hero
now my ego kicks in... how do I check which nvidia driver is installed? GeForce G100/PCIe/SSE2  I suppose is the name?:p
just out of wanting to learn, where do you learn all this stuff from? I'd like to be able to handle this myself in the future, haha:)
But is there some webpage where they cover this very specifically? Ubuntupage of some kind?
Uhm, that command says among other things "295.49-0ubuntu0.1 "
I have no experience in "digging" in codes nor desire to try, I'd smash my computer by the end of a week
but... what does that mean? Is it "the latest"? The most stable??
I think I'll leave well enough alone for now, lol:D
thanks a million for your help!
I wonder... i've got cpufreq installed, but I can't get it to run at 2.40Ghz, it always goes back to 1.20ghz or so... Is there a graphical user interface for configuring this?
cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep -i cores
cpu cores    : 2 cpu cores    : 2
what was that for?:D

I am not sure... I am having a senior moment, I don't know if that 2.4 is supposed to be cumulative of the multiple cores, or if what you are reading should be the combined speed. I am still waking up... I am grabbing cpufreq now, have never used it.
cool! Thanks for your time!
not to be silly... but is your scaling multiplier right in bios?
qu√©?
the bios I have in this computer is dated 2009 ... might be outdated, but how do I check if that is so?
not sure there is a function of that kind in my bios at all...
checking again then... rebooting:D
I really can't find any such function in the BIOS...
where are you getting the 1.2 from?
The 1.2?
Ah, from cpufreq-info -m
it shows two "analyzing CPU:" sections and both say "current CPU frequency is 1.20 GHz."
you given up too?:D
no... I am trying to figure out how to use this tool... and I am in a few other chats atm.. just be patient with me.
I do apologize, haha:)
all I have available is cpufreqd... and that command is not recognized... and... I am very tired.
alright, sleep well:)
I am still working... just not waking up... I can't sleep atm...
oh, well don't beat yourself up, I'm happy!
cat /proc/cpu | grep -i mhz
cat: /proc/cpu: No such file or directory
cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep -i mhz
mate, you're helping a lot of people, great, but sleep is important!!
cpu MHz        : 1200.000 power management: ts ttp tm stc 100mhzsteps hwpstate cpu MHz        : 1200.000 power management: ts ttp tm stc 100mhzsteps hwpstate
should have slept before that then=(
cheers:)
bios manipulation is no joke... you are best sticking to the utils
yeah, better leave well enough alone
let's make it more simple then; I'm on a acer aspire x3200... Can't find how do increase the cpu speed anywhere in the bios=(
have you looked at the manual from your manufacturer?
no.. no idea where it is haha):
haha, alright!
I can't find my computer model in the website... haha:)
Nvm, found it
